Dear Katrina Dahl Edmon:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
08/23/2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action
plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and
must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in
compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective
action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed
or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at 616-552-3662.
Sincerely,

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4152 Initial documentation
(1) At the time of admission, all of the following shall be
in the resident’s case record:
(g) Authorization to provide medical, dental, and
surgical care and treatment as provided in section 14 a
(1), (2), and (3) of 1973 PA 116, MCL 722.124a.
One of three youth files reviewed was missing a medical authorization card.
CCI Rule 400.4156 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; updated treatment plan
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign, and
date an updated treatment plan for each resident at
least once every 90-calendar days following the initial
treatment plan.
One of the three youth files reviewed was missing one updated treatment plan.

VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were 1 substantiated incident of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period. There was one investigation that resulted in one staff having a confirmed
case during this license period. The employee is no longer with the agency. During
the investigation it was determined that staff did not follow the agency medication
despensing procedures, left medication unsupervised, which allowed a resident to
take medication that is not prescribed to him.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency submitted three acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and has complied with each individual CAP.
Special Investigation 2023C044642: Rule 4142 Health Services policies and
procedures, medication dispensing. Staff did not follow the procedures for passing
medication and left the medication on the staff’s desk. The agency is compliant with
the CAP, the staff involved was terminated and all staff were retrained on
medication dispensing.
Special Investigation 2023C044642: Rule 4158 Behavior Management. Staff
grabbed youth by the ankle to prevent youth from grabbing a pencil, because he
thought youth was going to self-harm. CAP was submitted and approved on
11/10/2022. The staff involved resigned and all other staff were retrained on
behavior management procedures.
Special Investigation 2023C0000135: Rule 4112 Staff qualifications. Staff ran after
youth and play kicked him, chasing and horseplaying is not recommended and
jeopardizes youth’s safety. The CAP was approved on 01/17/2023. The agency is
compliant with the CAP and staff has been retrained on policy regarding
horseplaying.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on a review of the facility’s budget
and the agency financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator Assessment was done on time and was comprehensive and
reviewed all areas of noncompliance from the previous licensing review. During the
year the facility has experienced a decrease in the number of restraints, in addition
to enhanced training and efforts focusing on verbal de-escalation, medication
4

dispensing, and supervision. This also involved increased supervision, role playing,
and monitoring of staff utilizing verbal de-escalation techniques.
Staff and Youth Interviews
I interviewed staff, who reported feeling very supported by management,
participating in training, and feel that the agency is meeting the needs of the
youths.
I interviewed youths who reported feeling safe, having staff supervise them
appropriately, receiving therapy, enough food, medication, and all their needs are
being met.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The facility was found to be clean, neat, and appropriate. There were no issues of
concerns noted.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
